description: Probably borrowed from Middle Low German hoker.

entries.meaning: A peddler, a huckster, a person who sells easily transportable goods.
examples: The other [witness] was one Sim Doolittle, the fish hawker from Allerfoot, jogging home in his fish cart from Gledsmuir fair.

entries.meaning: Any dragonfly of the family Aeshnidae; a darner.

description: Inherited from Middle English hawkere, from Old English hafocere, hafecere; by surface analysis, hawk +â€Ž -er.

entries.meaning: Someone who breeds and trains hawks and other falcons; a falconer.
